newsitem.title: USA: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Index put buying remains mild.
newsitem.headline: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Index put buying remains mild.

text.p: Some market analysts may be seeing signs of a short-term top in U.S. stocks, but options investors are not playing along just yet, traders said Monday.
"There's still strong demand for calls," said Jack Callahan, an independent market maker in S&P 100 index .OEX options. He added that put buying was not extremely heavy.
Investors would likely buy puts for downside protection.
By midday, put volume in the OEX led call volume by 24,876 to 16,507, but that was not necessarily all put buying. The spot OEX index was down about a point at 863.
The OEX had reached a session low of 856.63.
The S&P 500 index .SPX was down 1.19 at about 886 after falling to 879.82 and September S&P 500 futures fell three points to 893.90. They reached 886.
The Dow industrial average was off 11 at about 7,677, off its 7,612 session low.
High bullishness and the failure of major indexes to crack key levels suggested to some analysts the market may be set for a correction.
Bernie Schaeffer, president of Cincinnati-based Investment Research Institute, said in a report the S&P 500 had reached "maximum overbought levels," which are a sign of vulnerability.
He added that additional vulnerability was indicated by the failure of S&P 500 futures to hold above the 900 level.

"Round numbers on optionable indices have often served as resistance levels in the bull market of the 1990s, particularly when accompanied -- as is the case right now -- by a buildup of call option open interest at those round number strikes," Schaeffer said.
In addition, he said a high level of investor optimism was also a reason for caution.

Schaeffer said he doubted short sellers or put option buyers would have much chance to profit from any correction because pullbacks should be "brief and contained well within the parameters of the long-term uptrend."

But Richard Scarlata, editor of the Sutton Advisory Letter, said in a report that important tops are now in place in most major stock indexes "and investors can expect at least a 20 percent correction over the next four months."
"July will be a cruel month for U.S. stocks," he said.
In terms of market activity Monday, Callahan said trading was on the quiet side as investors awaited the U.S. Federal Reserve's policy-setting meeting Tuesday and Wednesday.
"We're going to be on a watch here the next day or two," he said. "I imagine we'll tread water."
He added that when the market turned lower in mid-morning after early strength, put sellers turned into put buyers.
((Gregory Crawford, 312 408 8750))
E-mail: derivatives@reuters.com
